author: PreparetobePlaned
body: Norton is a joke and has been for a long time. It was only ever a consumer grade solution as far as I remember. NLOK sold their enterprise division to Broadcom in 2019. They aren't even competing in the same space as MSFT.

author: doggy_lovers
body: nvidia, amd, tsmc, and asml are your best chip companies. if you want value low pe chips buy qualcom or broadcom

author: DandelionBones
body: All good, I do the same constantly. Also AVGO is up 46.59% over the last year and 15.15% in the last month so I’m not sure how that’s a non performer. As for Intel, it’s a solid bet that isn’t going to go anywhere, even if the returns aren’t great. ETFs are for long term investing so that is probably why Intel is high up in the weighting’s.

author: Pmmenakedbitcoin
body: I'm invested in SMH and heavy weight on TSM, NVDIA, Intel, and Broadcom.

author: pilot64d
body:
Rivian is going to have the same Problem Tesla has, +1 other.   

I'd love to have a Tesla, but the nearest maintenance facility is an hour from me.

Rivian will have that problem plus the Ford Lightning.  If anyone is going to do a truck right it's Ford, and there are dealers everywhere.

Having said that, we are going through the same thing as in 1999; everything new tech related is soaring with no real production behind the business.  This is some Broadcom level pricing.

author: seigy
body: My take is $TSM makes high-end chips for NVDA & AMD, $GFS makes a mix of chips, $UMC makes legacy chips (main thing we are currently short on), $INTC makes their own chips.  There are others but I think these are the big fabs and foundries.  I believe $QCOM, $AVGO, $SKWS, $TXN make their own and get some from fans but I am not certain on them.  Other plays to consider are the equipment mfg who make the equipment, parts, and services the fabs are buying in order to make more chips.  Some big players here are $AMAT, $ASML, & $LRCX.

author: JaMMi01202
body:
MRVL and Broadcom (AVGO) should prosper from 5G in my opinion. 

Ex-RF engineer.

author: balance007
body: Simple math....both INTC and AVGO have relatively lower PE ratios and both pay a decent dividend....yes less upside compared to AMD and NVDA but much less downside if/when the market corrects.  If you dont have at least some long money in these two companies you are investing wrong.  Both companies are way too important to american tech national security to be allowed to fail even if we have a black swan event...

author: niftyifty
body: AVGO is up nearly 250% in five years. I’m not sure that qualifies as non-performing. This market has fucked with peoples Perspective. Either that, or never had any to begin with

author: PM_ME_DANK
body: $ABBV, $AVGO, $LMT

author: velcrolips
body: AVGO

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body: I’m there now. I started with about 200k last spring and am up to 337k on like 95 different positions, all shares. Probably too many small spec positions. My largest holdings are MSFT, Nvidia, Apple, Google, Broadcom AVGO, Teradyne TER, Tesla, Mastercard and Shopify.

author: balance007
body: Anything that was 'meta' related, NVDA/AMD graphics, QCOM/AVGO networking, MSFT/MTTR VR etc had a nice run after the FB meta announcement 2 weeks ago...everything is so high already though so who knows how much momentum it'll all have in the long run...rate hike fears will probably smash it down before long

body: And the fact you don’t believe makes it even better. Does the chat allow screenshots? I’ll post it for you so you can go to bed wondering how a dumb guy knew to buy 100,000’shares of axti at $2.50, 5,000 shares of DT at 37, 4,000 of SPT at $26, 10,000 of silc at $29, 500 avgo at 350, 10,000 attu at $6.70, debated mark Leonard (do you even know who that is? Probably not). Now let me find my return key. My list goes back older than you are kiddo. Bought interlinks before it was taken out, shoretel for a double on the sotp after its m5 acq, oh I can go way back from all of them. It started with 10K and now its multi million as I said. author: foundnoname

author: velcrolips
body: AVGO then 😂

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body:
About 2 years and about 30% percent a year. Started with 190k in a Schwab MMF, went to stocks (shares only) last March and am up to 348k. I’m about 90 different positions, I realize I have too many small positions. My large positions have done very well though. NVDA, AVGO, TER, TTD, MA, BRKB, C, BAC, SHOP, TSLA, ZBRA, GOOG, AAPL are my large blue chip holdings.

Edit : I realize I’ve lucked out with timing and won’t get 30% a year every year but I’m thankful for the portfolio I’ve managed to put together and believe it could outperform long term or get dumpster fucked who knows.

author: czechyerself
body: Probably not. They pay a dividend - a big one - so innovation is not going to always be #1 with them. They’re probably more like the new Broadcom

author: KookyManster
body:
Intel will bounce back but even the CEO states that it will take a couple of years to see results. Several Enterprise companies have switched to AMD at the moment and it will take some strong convincing from Intel for them to change back. Companies do not like to spend time and money on engineering cost unless they have to or there is substantial improvements as well as cost reduction. 

I would suggest AVGO (broadcom) if you're looking for a solid big cap chip company. AVGO is also diversified in SW and data center equipment...a strong growing trend in these products.

author: velcrolips
body: NET CRM NVDA AMD XILINX MSFT GOOG AVGO SOFI

author: 95Daphne
body:
While it has just been NVDA/AMD at times, since the Nasdaq bottomed on October 4th, there have been plenty of semiconductor stocks that have done really well:

AVGO: +18.6%

AMAT: +20.8%

(two holdings of mine)

LRCX: +23.7%

(was a holding of mine but I let myself get spooked about the way semis were running, I shouldn't have sold it)

MU: +22%

QCOM: +45%

While some of them have been bleh, most SOXX stocks look more like AVGO and AMAT than SWKS and QRVO, and it's a bit of an under the radar reason why the Nasdaq got back to a record and looked fine underneath until a couple weeks ago.

author: colorabro
body: Broadcom, the little engine that could

author: truckerslife411
body: $AVGO in August 2020

author: MicroChapLong
body: Norton lifelock sells consumer cyber security. It will grow as people continue to buy consumer cyber security solutions. They are one of two only games in town for this solution. They used to be in the penalty box for terrible execution but now have solid new management as evidenced by recent performance of double digit rev growth from low single digits. They divested a major piece of the biz to avgo so now it’s consumer pure play. I can go on and on. Tell me what you need

author: MicroChapLong
body: They sold Symantec to avgo so you aren’t looking at PF. This is a turnaround story that just started a few quarters ago. It’s a double digit revenue grower now and will be $45+ within 3-5 years based on forward eps target which is high probability to achieve

body: Thank you! I've heard good things about Broadcom I'll definitely take a look.

author: KookyManster
body:
Income stocks pays pennies compared to blue chips.
I'm not a fan of investing solely for the dividends, unless you have thousands of shares if a high paying dividend. 
AVGO for example is a solid blue chip/SW company with great dividend yield.

author: badpauly
body:
This is a list of the top 20 companies that experienced the largest change in insider shares in the last seven (7) days.
The SEC defines an insider as any officer, director or 10% shareholder. It is not illegal for these people to buy or sell their own shares.
In fact, since most of them get paid in stock options, it is expected. However, it is illegal for them to trade on inside information
that has not been made public. So for example if there are drug trial results that are bad and not public,
insiders cannot dump shares. That said, many people have observed that insiders - in general - seem to have a good
track record at timing their purchases.  All trades that are marked as part of a 10b5 plan are excluded from this report.

author: Deeperfuckinvalue
body:
I am officially down 35k with my life savings and currently decided to live in my car :) i started with scalping , had some success but couldnt see it doing long term. Switched to spreads and thought of doing PUt credit spreads and iron condors. Took positions in GPN, CAR thinking they were the safest play ( what could go wrong with AVIS). Oh well ran up 300% the day after earnings. Last week took apple bear credit spread and guess what , ALL TIME HIGH :) so not sure if anything wrong with my trading or just bad luck ! 

Are you still doing spreads ?

author: More_Surround
body: I sold PayPal, Global Payments and Visa two weeks ago. I couldn’t continue the losses and figured I could make money elsewhere.

author: half-spin
body:
There is already the original metaverse, called second life. I was blown away that Zuck did not even once mention it. they are basically making a more modern version of this, and they are going to try to shove their oculus to everyone's face. 

The value proposition is valid, it is that 3d gaming is the future of social chatter. 

The VR push  however is going  to be a major flop. No amount of high tech is going to change the fact that a blindfold is not something you want to wear for long. Also, Facebook sells attention, and AR is the opposite of attention, it's distraction. 

Unity will benefit enormously from this,  but mobile gaming will lose a lot of momentum for a long time. 

Here is what people buy in second life: Avatars, avatar skins, avatar clothes, penises, vaginas, sexy clothes, even more sexy clothes. Basically take the most superficial and vain doll-dressing app and pump it up by 10 times or so, that's the future. No, it won't be the hub for tech and work and education and research, it will be as vapid and vain as facebook and instagram are now. 

Facebook will probably push its own, controlled and censored "crypto" to people. This will be their most controversial move,  but maybe their lobbyists are already in agreement with US govt. This is about ensuring that the next global payments system is controlled by the US govt.
